rOpenSci Newsletter

Aug 3, 2020


Software 📦

CRAN: GitHub:

New Packages

  • The first version (v0.1.0) of dittodb is on CRAN - a test environment for database requests. It went through rOpenSci software review recently - check out the reviews. Checkout the docs to get started.

New Versions

  • rdpla is now archived on cran. You can still install it from GitHub but it is no longer maintained.
  • A new version (v1.1-3) of suppdata is on CRAN - downloading supplementary data from published manuscripts. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.
  • A new version (v1.1.0) of spocc is on CRAN - an interface to many species occurrence data sources. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of ckanr is on CRAN - client for the CKAN API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v1.0.0) of crul is on CRAN - an R6 based HTTP client for R made for developers. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.5.0) of mapr is on CRAN - visualize species occurrence data. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.
  • A new version (v0.9.0) of gistr is on CRAN - work with GitHub Gists. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.2.10) of ropenaq is on CRAN - air quality data from the open data platform OpenAQ. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.0) of paleobioDB is on CRAN - download and process data from the Paleobiology database. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.8) of robotstxt is on CRAN - robots.txt parser and Webbot/Spider/Crawler permissions checker. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v2.1.2) of ijtiff is on CRAN - comprehensive TIFF I/O with full support for ImageJ TIFF files. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • Two new versions (v2.0.2/v2.0.3) of EML are on CRAN - read and write ecological metadata language files. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v3.2.0) of rgbif is on CRAN - interface to the Global Biodiversity Information Facility API. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the occurrence manual to get started.
  • A new version (v1.3.0) of credentials is on CRAN - tools for managing ssh and git credentials. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the docs to get started.
  • A new version (v0.7.0) of ssh is on CRAN - secure shell (SSH) client for R. See the release notes for changes. Checkout the vignette to get started.



Software Review ✔


Software review is now accepting submissions again.

We accept community contributed packages via our software review system - an open software review system, sorta like scholarly paper review, but way better. We’ll highlight newly onboarded packages here. A huge thanks to our reviewers, who do a lot of work reviewing (see the blog post on our review system), and the authors of the packages!

If you want to be a reviewer fill out this short form, and we’ll ping you when there’s a submission that fits in your area of expertise.


No new submissions or approved submissions.



Citations

The following 20 works use/cite rOpenSci software:

  • Scharmüller et al. used bib2df, plotly, rgbif, taxize and webchem in their paper Standartox: Standardizing Toxicity Data 1
  • Nguyen et al. used MODIStsp in their paper Factors affecting urban electricity consumption: a case study in the Bangkok Metropolitan Area using an integrated approach of earth observation data and data analysis 2
  • Upadhya et al. used rtimicropem in their paper mmaqshiny v1.0: R-Shiny package to explore Air-Quality Mobile-Monitoring data 3
  • Rahman et al. used rtweet in their paper Twitter and Census Data Analytics to Explore Socioeconomic Factors for Post-COVID-19 Reopening Sentiment 4
  • Colling et al. used magick in their paper A multilab registered replication of the attentional SNARC effect 5
  • Lam et al. used skimr in their paper Use of random forest analysis to quantify the importance of the structural characteristics of beta-glucans for prebiotic development 6
  • Deconinck et al. used rnaturalearth in their paper A high-quality genetic reference database for European commercial fishes reveals substitution fraud of processed Atlantic cod (Gadus morhua) and common sole (Solea solea) at different steps in the Belgian supply chain 7
  • Bohora Schlickmann et al. used rgbif in their paper Specific leaf area is a potential indicator of tree species sensitive to future climate change in the mixed Subtropical Forests of southern Brazil 8
  • Shrestha & Shrestha used geojsonio in their paper Group segmentation and heterogeneity in the choice of cooking fuels in post-earthquake Nepal 9
  • Crowley et al. used rotl and taxize in their paper Identifying Suspect Bat Reservoirs of Emerging Infections 10
  • Joyce et al. used rgbif in their paper Checklist of the vascular flora of the Sunda-Sahul Convergence Zone 11
  • Camacho used rtweet in their paper Sentiment mapping: Point pattern analysis of sentiment classified twitter data 12
  • Haußner & Klika used rtweet in their paper Who Is Connected to Whom? A Twitter-Based Network Analysis of Members of the European Parliament Elected in 2019 13
  • Petersen et al. used rgbif in their paper Urban aliens and threatened near-naturals: Land-cover affects the species richness of alien- and threatened species in an urban-rural setting 14
  • Lindberg et al. used rgbif in their paper Increased above‐ground resource allocation is a likely precursor for independent evolutionary origins of annuality in the Pooideae grass subfamily 15
  • Donnellan et al. used hunspell in their paper How are Curiosity and Interest Different? 16
  • Gold used taxize in their paper Design and Implementation of Environmental DNA Metabarcoding Methods for Monitoring the Southern California Marine Protected Area Network 17
  • Lenoir et al. used taxize and rgbif in their paper Species better track climate warming in the oceans than on land 18
  • De Almeida Monteiro Melo Ferraz et al. used rentrez in their paper Follicular extracellular vesicles enhance meiotic resumption of domestic cat vitrified oocytes 19
  • Joo et al. used fulltext in their paper A decade of movement ecology 20



From the Forum

We have a discussion forum (using Discourse) for the rOpenSci community. It’s a really nice way to have conversations on the internet. From time to time we’ll highlight recent discussions of interest.


A few new use cases were shared in the forum over the past two weeks since our last newsletter:

  • Pedro Rocha contributed our first use case in Portuguese! Extraindo tabelas de documentos pdf em R com Tabulizer; it leveraged the tabulizer package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Tom Paskhalis
  • Zhi Yang shared: Creating a self-updating GitHub README using rtweet and GitHub Actions; the use case employed the rtweet package, an rOpenSci package maintained by Michael Kearney
  • Rayna Harris shared: Spanish and English blogs on how to use rtweet and magick; it used the rtweet and magick packages, rOpenSci packages maintained by Michael Kearney and Jeroen Ooms, respectively



Call For Maintainers

Part of the mission of rOpenSci is making sustainable software that users can rely on. Some software maintainers need to give up maintenance due to a variety of circumstances. When that happens we try to find new maintainers. Check out our guidance for taking over maintenance of a package.

We’ve had nine recent examples of maintainer transitions within rOpenSci:

  • RSelenium: now maintained by Ju Kim
  • chromer: now maintained by Paula Andrea
  • qualtRics: now maintained by Julia Silge
  • rsnps: now maintained by Julia Gustavsen and Sina Rüeger
  • webchem: now maintained by Erik Sapper
  • mregions: in process of moving to maintenance by VLIZ
  • rWBclimate: now maintained by Sergio Ibarra-Espinosa and Amanda Rehbein
  • rinat: now maintained by Stéphane Guillou



Get involved with rOpenSci

We maintain a Contributing Guide that can help direct you to the right place, whether you want to make code contributions, non-code contributions, or other things like sharing use cases.





Keep up with rOpenSci

  • Mailing list: Sign up with an email address to get this newsletter sent to your inbox -> ropensci.org/#subscribe
  • Alternatively, you can subscribe to this newsletter via our XML feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.xml or our JSON feed at https://news.ropensci.org/feed.json
  • rOpenSci on Twitter: @ropensci
  • The rOpenSci blog at ropensci.org/blog - you can subscribe in any RSS aggregator, or manually via https://ropensci.org/feed.xml. We also announce new blog posts on our Twitter account.
